body.p: Montreal 21st March 1864.
My dear Sir—

It is long since I have had this pleasure;
but during the whole of the past winter which has been a
very sickly one no doubt in consequence of its extraordinary
mildness—I have scarcely found time to write home. Correspondence
is a luxury in which I cannot often indulge, especially as my
duties increase in college, as do also my literary calls. In
November last you wrote me “ I presume you have no time for
anything but your own work, or else your fathers memoir
ought to have been finished long since. ” You were right in
your first supposition—the memoir (or nearly all) had been
long finished and sent to England to my family there for
perusal—I had to delay till I got materials very few of
which however I did not possess before my visit to England
three years since. They wished to publish it in pamphlet form
and distribute it to the congregation (K. K. Shaar Ashmaim?) on
consideration however we decided not to do so, and the M.S.?
remained in London at my request until I had an opportunity
to bring it out. Mr W. Benjamin has recently returned from
England & brought it with him, having no copy I did not wish
to trust the mail. As you were the first to express a desire
to obtain full particulars of my late revered and gifted parents
career I send it now to you, although perhaps a London
periodical, would be the more appropriate vehicle for
publication. Of this you may be assured no one in England
(not even Beuisch with whom I am intimate) except my own
family has seen it, and no one in America, except the Joseph's
family here. It was Mrs J. H. J. who said it ought to be
printed. I will leave it to you to decide whether you think
it of sufficient general interest for your new volume. Mr
Abraham Joseph goes to new York tomorrow and takes it
with him. He will probably send it on by mail to Philada

I risk only about half what I have written of the Biography
awaiting another opportunity for the balance, I should say
the whole will make about 45 or 50 pages of M.S such as I send. If
these the last ten pages are not yet written, but of course would
be ready should you publish them. Should you not do so, please
do not return the M. S. by mail, I prefer another opportunity, again
even should you print, I must ask you to ? the copy for me.
I will leave it to you to decide whether my name should be
attached to it. Please let me hear what you think of this
before you print. I would like while the type stands to have
150 or 200 copies taken for a pamphlet—same as my “Sanatory
institutions” was done. Permit me to explain how this was.
The articles were published in a monthly like yours—enough
was set up for a sheet or half sheet I forget which
printed off for pamphlet, and served for two months supply
to the magazine. I need not say that I of course expect to
“pay the difference.”

Mr Abraham Joseph wants
two of your 12 mo Bibles—the ordinary calf binding I presume
Please send them (or if you like to ? the sale with a
couple more) to the following address A. Joseph Esq care
Titus Smythe & Co. 151 Front St New York upon whom
(i.e. Messrs Smythe) you can draw at sight for the amount
of his two copies. This leads me to advise you to
address S. Benjamin (Messrs Benjamin Bros Manchester)
for the amount of his indebtedness to you. You are aware
that I applied to them when here, but without success.
Mrs John Levey is going to New York to open a Boarding
House might also pay and Hebrew if you would write
a line to Rev S. M. Isaacs, she would no doubt pay
him if instructed to do so by you. Apropos des bottes
Rev S. M. I is immortalising Jewish orthodox ministers
in his “Diary” in a manner, for which it seems to me

we ought to be duly thankful. Punch? would not do it better
whether the character such as he forms is no better than it
should be, whether it would bear close analysis as far as
moral principles, correct motives of actions are concerned,
cest une autre chose. I fancy that you, not more than I would
like to wear the cap so becoming to “a cunning Isaac” if not
to a sincere good man and a Jew. At all events my “leaves from the
life of a Jewish Minister” cannot be much more ?, so I am doubly encouraged to send them

Mrs Davis and her son seem temporarily
fixed here, whether permanently so we shall see. Young
Mr Nathan whom you introduced to us at the commencement
of the winter, and who spent a few evenings with us, suddenly
disappeared—whither I know not—Has he turned up in
your part of the world.

I have lately been dragged into a new
Literary organisation. They have passed me the complement of
electing me president; but I dont think I shall accept of the
office. I met at a social party by invitation & by his
wish, the Bishop of New Jersey. He says he knows you
and Dr Raphall. He also knew my uncle David Meldola.
He is a very jolly fellow, and we took champagne—something
in which you never, I very seldom indulge—together;
you will say I have been keeping Purim before its time.
Well I will at least wish you a merry one, and
conclude—if not my toast—my letter with wishing
you many happy returns Hebrew, and with
my wife's united kind regards
I remain yours truly
My brother Sam the Hazan is engaged
to Miss Henry niece of the late
D. A. Lindo.
As nearly all to whom I have spoken have
at least one of Grace Aguilars works
they did not wish to subscribe for them all again, imply some might have
them ordered. I did not ask any of the Pala?, for they dont read.
CIRCULAR
OF THE
Council of the Montreal Natural History Society,

The Council of the Natural History Society of Montreal have still to deplore the very defective
state of their collection of mammals. The recent large increase of the working members of the society, its improved
status at home and reputation abroad, and the removal of the Society to their present commodious building, all
demand that this collection should attain the same completeness as that of the Canadian birds, now in the Museum,
and become equally useful for reference. The Council would therefore respectfully represent to Naturalists, Sports-
men and others, that they could much advance the desired object by sending their specimens to the Society for pre-
servation; and to those kindred Societies who might also feel disposed to co-operate, the duplicate specimens of
minerals, fossils, and birds, both American and foreign, now in possession of the Society, would readily be made
available where wanted. In publishing the subjoined list of quadrupeds chiefly wanted, the Council desire to solicit
the aid of the public generally to supply them, convinced that their efforts to foster and advance the special branch
of science to which they devote themselves, will be appreciated.
ABRAHAM DE SOLA, LL. D. ,
JOHN LEEMING,
Montreal, January, 1864:
